Technical Assistance Report 
 
Project Number: 42339-01 
Regional—Policy and Advisory Technical Assistance (R-PATA) 
May 2010 
 
 
 
Improving Liquidity of Bond Markets in ASEAN+3  
(Financed by the Investment Climate Facilitation Fund under the 
Regional Cooperation and Integration Financing Partnership Facility) 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The 1997 Asian financial crisis showed that an overdependence on the banking sector 
could make the entire financial system highly vulnerable. At that time, overdependence on bank 
financing had forced borrowers to be exposed to excessive short-term foreign exchange risk 
when financing long-term projects where the revenues were denominated in local currency.  
Such currency and maturity mismatches contributed to the Asian financial crisis as capital 
inflows came to a sudden stop and capital flight occurred. It demonstrated that an alternative 
funding source to short-term bank loans needed to be developed. 
2.  Based  on  the  lessons  from  the  crisis,  ASEAN+3  (Association  of  Southeast  Asian 
Nations, the People's Republic of China, Japan, and the Republic of Korea) launched the Asian 
Bond Markets Initiative (ABMI) in 2003 to develop local currency bond markets in Asia as an 
alternative funding source to short-term bank loans in either local or foreign currencies. The goal 
of ABMI is to strengthen local currency bond markets to improve the resilience of financial 
systems, prevent maturity and currency mismatches, and help mobilize the region’s abundant 
savings to finance long-term investments.  
3.  In addition to the rapid growth of the ASEAN+3 bond markets, shares held by foreign 
investors have recently increased. If this trend continues, it will promote the diversification of 
market participants, thereby contributing to enhance the stability of those bond markets. In 
terms of promoting the diversification of market participants, legal frameworks and business 
practices need to be harmonized in bond markets across the region to reduce the cost and risk 
of bond transactions and bond holdings. This will also contribute to the further growth of the 
bond markets and market integration in ASEAN+3. 
4.  The ABMI has focused on four areas: (i) promoting the issuance of bonds denominated 
in  local  currency,  (ii)  facilitating  the  demand  for  such  bonds,  (iii) improving  the  regulatory 
framework,  and  (iv)  improving  related  infrastructure  for  bond  markets.  Task  forces  were 
established under each of the four key areas.     
5.  One of the priority activities for Task Force 4, which is responsible for improving related 
infrastructure, is increasing the liquidity of bond markets by establishing effective primary dealer 
systems in the ASEAN+3 countries. These countries have requested the Asian Development 
Bank (ADB) to provide technical assistance (TA) to (i) assess the necessity, feasibility, and cost 
and benefits of establishing primary dealer systems in the countries where no such system 
exists, or (ii) improve existing primary dealer systems. The design and monitoring framework is 
in Appendix 1. The TA will be implemented in line with the work plan of Task Force 4. The 
concept paper of the TA was approved on 29 July 2009.1 
                                                
1  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB's website on 1 February 2010.

2   
 
II.  ISSUES 
A.        Role of Government Bonds 
 
6.  As government bonds play a pivotal and dominant role in not only bond markets but also 
financial markets and serve as a critical tool for government financing, the governments in the 
region have reformed their bond markets in recent years, supported by several development 
partners,  including ADB.  The development of government bond  markets  is  also  crucial  to 
achieving the ABMI’s goal of promoting growth and stability in domestic and regional bond 
markets.  
7.  In most countries, the government bond market is the most important market in the 
financial system because of its dominant size and its role in debt financing. Government bonds 
comprised 71.2% of the total local currency bond outstanding at the end of September 2009 in 
the ASEAN countries, the People's Republic of China, and the Republic of Korea. Banks and 
other financial institutions such as insurance companies and pension funds invest and trade in 
government bonds for asset, liquidity, and risk management purposes. Government bonds are 
commonly used as a monetary policy tool by central banks. They also function as the pricing 
benchmark  for  corporate  bonds  and  reveal  information  on  current  and  future  monetary 
conditions as reflected in its interest rate movements.  
B.   Liquidity of the Government Bond Market 
 
8.  For the primary market to function effectively, the government has to consider the timing 
and frequency of bond issuances, and the type, maturity, and coupon rate of bonds based on 
investors' needs by keeping a close relationship and communication with dealers and investors. 
The government also needs to continue issuing bonds to provide liquidity, help create a series 
of benchmarks, and promote the sustainable development of the bond market, in addition to 
financing their financial needs and expenditures. The issuing method, including auctions and 
syndicated underwriting, should be market-based, and reopening and buyback schemes are 
also needed to enhance liquidity. The government has to disclose bond issuance information, 
including the issuance schedule, the volume by maturity, and the lot and frequency of each 
issuance, and to announce auction and underwriting results. These are needed to improve the 
transparency of government bond issuances and enhance the predictability of bond issuances 
for dealers and investors.  
 
9.  For bond dealers and investors, liquidity in a secondary market is highly desirable. A 
deep and liquid secondary market helps strengthen the confidence of investors and dealers in 
their purchase of bonds in a primary market, as they know they will be able to trade the bonds 
easily in the secondary market with little or no impact on market prices. Active transactions can 
help to promote broader participation by and diversification of dealers and investors, reduce bid 
and ask price spreads, and lower financing costs for bond issuers. Liquid bond markets can also 
promote fair pricing through competition among dealers and can contribute to the formation of a 
reliable yield curve as a pricing benchmark.  
 
10.  The liquidity in a secondary market is enhanced by active market-making operations by 
dealers and investors. Market-making operations are supported by a diversified base of market 
intermediaries and institutional investors, appropriate instruments and transaction methods, and 
a systematic framework for bond transactions. A certain minimum level of market liquidity and

3 
reliable benchmarks are critical because they enable market participants to trade and invest in a 
fair and transparent manner and improve the price discovery function. In addition to regular 
issuance of benchmark bonds, reopening and refinancing operations by the government enable 
fragmented markets to be consolidated and standardized to maintain minimum liquidity. A stable 
clearance and settlement system is an important market infrastructure for active trading among 
dealers, and "delivery versus payment" settlement is the best practice because it can reduce 
counterparty  risk  and  transaction  costs.  Complementary  market  infrastructures,  such  as  a 
repurchase agreement (repo) market, and derivatives and futures markets for risk hedging, 
need to be developed to enable dealers to trade smoothly in a secondary market and to build a 
large  inventory  of  bonds,  and  investors  to  take  a  large  and  long  position  in  their  bond 
investments.  
 
11.  Transparency  is  important  for  improving  liquidity  in  a  secondary  market  and  an 
information dissemination scheme for bond transactions needs to be developed. The majority of 
bond trading is carried out through over-the-counter markets, which are not so transparent and 
can impede the price discovery function. To enhance transparency and promote trading in a 
secondary market, adequate pre- and post-trade price information needs to be disclosed. On 
the other hand, some information, including the proposed bid and ask prices by dealers to their 
clients in pre-trade should be confidential and individual market participants should remain 
anonymous. Disclosure of such information could hamper market-making operations by dealers. 
Anonymity is also an important factor in both pre- and post-trade stages because disclosing 
such information would enable dealers' and investors' positions and strategies to be guessed, 
impeding their active transaction and intermediation. It is necessary to assess the type of 
information to be gathered and disclosed in line with best practices on effective information 
dissemination. 
 
C.   Primary Dealer System 
 
12.  A primary dealer system is a group of selected dealers given some exclusive privileges, 
such  as access  to  primary  issuance or other special auctions  and participation  in  special 
meetings  with  the  government,  in  exchange  for  the  obligations  of  (i)  full  participation  in 
government bond auctions in a substantial and consistent manner of bidding and purchasing, (ii) 
conducting market-making in a secondary market by proposing competitive bid and ask prices, 
and (iii) reporting and providing market information and advice to the government.  
 
13.  In the early stage of the bond market development when the investor base is thin and 
the expertise and resources needed to develop the bond market are scarce, the primary market 
often cannot absorb the supply of government bonds efficiently because of the large size of 
government bond issuances. Although underwriting by a special syndicate or private placement 
contributes to the government's financing in a primary market, these types of issuance can 
impede liquidity in a secondary market as they tend to place government bonds directly to 
investors or last holders without trading though dealers. The government bond issuance should 
be  shifted from  underwriting and/or private  placement  to  auction  in order  to enhance  the 
effectiveness of market making operation by dealers. A primary dealer system can be an 
effective solution to ensure government bond issuances through auctions because the system 
imposes primary dealers to bid and purchase newly issued bonds substantially in auctions. In 
addition, by requiring primary dealers to trade government bonds competitively in a secondary 
market as one of the obligations of their membership, a primary dealer system can help to 
improve liquidity in the government bond markets. The feasibility of market-making operations 
by primary dealers is a key determinant for the introduction of a primary dealer system to 
improve liquidity in the government bond market. Market-making operations can be supported

4   
by  (i)  a  certain  amount  of  liquidity  and  a  series  of  benchmarks;  (ii)  market  infrastructure 
supporting bond transactions,  including a  stable  clearance and  settlement  system, a  repo 
market, and a futures and derivatives market; and (iii) appropriate disclosure of information, 
including anonymous trading in bond transactions. 
 
14.  There  is a  risk  that a primary  dealer  system could  lead  to  a collusive  group  with 
exclusive privileges. To ensure a competitive primary dealer system, it is necessary to require 
primary dealers to meet their obligations including competitive bidding and purchasing. Their 
performance in market-making operations in a secondary market needs to be closely monitored. 
The government needs to develop a monitoring and reporting system and to enhance its 
monitoring capacity because it is difficult to monitor primary dealers' market-making operations if 
most bond transactions are conducted in the over-the-counter market.  
 
15.  Although some of the ASEAN+3 countries have introduced a primary dealer system and 
have  succeeded  in  stable  financing  and  liquidity  enhancement,  others  have  either  not 
introduced a primary dealer system or have the systems that are not functioning well. In some 
cases, minimum liquidity, dealers and investors base, and supporting market infrastructures 
have not matured enough to allow primary dealers to assume the responsibility of market-
making. In other cases, as the responsibilities and privileges of a primary dealer are not well 
balanced, there is little incentive for a dealer to be qualified as a primary dealer. In others, 
competition among primary dealers for market-making operations is not maintained due to the 
lack of adequate monitoring system.      
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
16.  The impact of the TA will be comprehensive development of domestic and regional bond 
markets in ASEAN+3 countries as an alternative funding source that will reduce borrowers' 
dependency on short-term bank loans and minimize currency and maturity mismatches. The 
outcome of the TA is expected to improve liquidity of the government bond markets through the 
establishment or strengthening of effective primary dealer systems. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
17.  Design a primary dealer system for countries that do not have such systems.  The 
TA will comprehensively examine the necessity, feasibility, and costs and benefits of introducing 
a primary dealer system into the countries that do not have such systems. It will also assess the 
development and maturity of each bond market, focusing on the extent to which bond dealers 
can conduct adequate market-making operations. The assessment will review the government 
bond issuance policy, issuance methods in a primary market, the level of minimum liquidity, 
relevant market infrastructures including a trading style or platform, a repo market, derivatives 
and futures  market,  and a  clearing and  settlement  system; and  an  information disclosure 
scheme. Based on the assessment, the TA will develop an action plan to introduce a primary 
dealer system, or an alternative approach to enhancing market-making functions and improving 
the liquidity of bond markets.  
 
18.  Strengthen an existing primary dealer system.  The TA will examine the performance 
of existing primary dealer systems, in terms of the effectiveness of the market-making function. 
It will identify the advantages and disadvantages of primary systems, and the factors that 
account for weaknesses and strengths of them. The TA will focus on the competitiveness of

5 
market-making operations among primary dealers and will assess regulatory measures to keep 
the primary dealer system contestable and the performance monitoring system to ensure their 
market-making operations. The government bond issuance policy and market infrastructure to 
support market-making operations will be reviewed. Based on this assessment, the TA will 
propose policy recommendations to strengthen existing primary dealer systems in the context of 
enhancing market-making operations and improving liquidity in a secondary market.  
 
19.  A workshop to disseminate the outcomes of the TA and a training on how to establish or 
improve a primary dealer system will be held for government officials and market participants in 
ASEAN+3 member countries. The outcomes of the TA and the reports will be shared with 
member countries at the ABMI meeting and other dissemination seminars. 
 
20.  The TA will target the bond markets of ASEAN, the People's Republic of China, and the 
Republic  of  Korea.  ADB  has  been  providing  continuous  country-level  assistance  for  bond 
market development to a number of countries in ASEAN and these have been based on 
strategies such as the financial sector road map of each country partnership strategy and 
sustained policy dialogue by the Southeast Asia Department. The TA will be designed and 
implemented so that it is consistent with these strategies, ongoing projects, and the outputs of 
previous assistance.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
21.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,250,000. It will be financed on a grant basis by the 
Investment Climate Facilitation Fund under the Regional Cooperation and Integration Financing 
Partnership Facility,2 and administered by ADB. The cost estimates and financing plan are in 
Appendix 2.    
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
22.  The  TA  will  be  administered  by  the  Office  of  Regional  Economic  Integration  in 
coordination with ASEAN+3 under the ABMI Task Force 4 work plan. The Office of Regional 
Economic Integration will also cooperate with the Southeast Asia Department and will exchange 
information  on  bond  markets  in  the  ASEAN+3  countries.  The  TA  will  be  disbursed  in 
accordance with the ADB's Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook.3 The design and 
monitoring  framework  in  Appendix  1  will  be  used  to  track  and  evaluate  progress  in 
implementation. The TA will be implemented over 20 months and is expected to begin in May 
2010 and be completed by December 2011.  
 
23.  The TA will require 20 person-months of international consulting services and 20 person-
months of national consulting services. The consultants will be engaged by ADB as individual 
consultants in accordance with ADB's Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended 
from time to time). The international consultants will include a bond market specialist, who will 
play the role of team leader, and a capital market infrastructure specialist. National consultants 
with expertise in the same areas will be engaged for the same length of time to provide support 
to the international consultants. Outline of the terms of reference for consultants are in Appendix 
3.

24.  The team leader will coordinate the input of all other consultants. The consultants will 
submit (i) an inception report, within 1 month after the TA commencement; (ii) an interim 
progress  report,  including  an assessment of the  current  situation  of  each  bond  market  in 
ASEAN, the People's Republic of China, and the Republic of Korea, (iii) a draft final report 16 
months after TA commencement, and (iv) a final report after receiving comments from member 
countries in ASEAN+3 and ADB. The progress of the TA will be discussed at the ABMI Task 
Force 4 meeting and reported to the ABMI steering meeting. The results and outputs will be 
shared  with  relevant  government  officials  and  market  participants  through  dissemination 
seminars and workshops as well as with ABMI member countries.   
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
25.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,250,000 to be financed on 
a grant basis by the Investment Climate Facilitation Fund under the Regional Cooperation and 
Integration Financing Partnership Facility for Improving Liquidity of Bond Markets in ASEAN+3, 
and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  International Consultants 
1.  Bond  market  specialist  (10  person-months).  As  team  leader,  the  specialist  will  be 
responsible for the overall management and implementation of the technical assistance (TA), the 
timely delivery of high-quality reports, and arranging workshops and trainings. As a bond market 
specialist, the consultant must have sufficient knowledge of bond markets and at least 10 years' 
practical experience of bond market infrastructure, particularly a primary dealer system. The tasks 
and responsibilities of the specialist include the following:     
(i)  Assess the preconditions for introducing a primary dealer system and evaluate the 
necessity, feasibility, and costs and benefits of establishing a primary dealer system 
and its effectiveness for improving liquidity.  
(ii)  Assess the effectiveness of existing primary dealer systems in member countries 
and identify their successes and failures.  
(iii)  Develop  a  road  map  for  establishing  an  appropriate  primary  dealer  system  or 
propose an alternative approach for improving liquidity. The road map will provide 
guidance on how to develop preconditions for introducing a primary dealer system, 
and design a tailor-made model of a primary dealer system, including the selection, 
definition, responsibilities and privileges of a primary dealer, and the methods of 
communication and dialogue between the government and primary dealers. The 
proposed model can be wide and may range from a rigid scheme with an obligation 
to conduct market-making operations to a simple market dealer system. It may 
include a syndicate group of financial institutions in a primary market with certain 
market-making obligations. It should be flexible enough to be changed as each bond 
market develops. 
(iv)   Provide recommendations for strengthening existing primary dealer systems in the 
context of enhancing market-making operations by primary dealers and improving 
the liquidity of bond markets. 
(v)   Assist  the  Office  of  Regional  Economic  Integration  in  arranging  dissemination 
seminars and workshops under the ABMI. 
(vi)   Prepare a comprehensive report to improve the liquidity of the bond market through 
the establishment or improvement of an effective primary dealer system in ASEAN, 
People's Republic of China, and Republic of Korea under the ABMI. 
 
2.   Capital market infrastructure specialist (10 person-months). The specialist will assist the 
bond market specialist. The specialist should be familiar with auction and underwriting processes 
in a primary market and bond market infrastructures, including repo markets, derivatives and 
futures  markets,  and  clearing  and  settlement  systems.  The  tasks  and  responsibilities  of  the 
specialist include the following: 
(i)  Assess the current development level of each bond market by focusing on market 
infrastructures in primary and secondary markets.  
(ii)  Identify the impediments to liquidity of each bond market. 
(iii)  Provide recommendations for improving bond market infrastructures to enhance 
liquidity in bond markets.  
(iv)   Provide  advisory  services  and  training  for  government  officials  and  market 
participants on policy issues based on recommendations of the TA to improve the 
liquidity of the bond market.
